snippet.textDisplay:
hi james, you need to whisk it for longer until it becomes stiff <-- that's how you get the cool looking effect.


i made it with 1tbsp instant coffee, 0.75 tbsp sugar, 1tbsp room temp water. In my electric mixer for about 8 minutes until it formed stiff peaks like a meringue.
snippet.textOriginal:
hi james, you need to whisk it for longer until it becomes stiff <-- that's how you get the cool looking effect.


i made it with 1tbsp instant coffee, 0.75 tbsp sugar, 1tbsp room temp water. In my electric mixer for about 8 minutes until it formed stiff peaks like a meringue.

snippet.textDisplay:
​ James Hoffmann This would be a great opportunity to do an exhaustive test of ALL of the plant milks and plant creamers!!! I meant, oat milk "minor figures' bran in particular is the most popular right now, but maybe a more elusive plant milk works better. Things that come to mind: Macadamia milk, tiger nut milk, rice milk, pumpkin seed...There are also many different brands and type of creamers. Some better for foaming than others. I think what I would be most interested in hearing from you and your advanced coffee palette is just how the various flavours of milks compliment coffee.


In my own experience I find the plant milk options at Starbucks to be extremely disappointing. Soy, Almond, Coconut.
I chose soy because it is the most neutral in flavour, and I personally don't have any problems digesting it, however I know many do. On one occasion I ordered to coconut milk for my drink--now I'm not sure if the person just pulled a bad shot, or overheated the milk but the flavours just did not meld well. The coconut made it taste burnt (I have tried it on a few occasions and this flavour is consistent). Almond on the other hand I just never cared for. The flavour is too nutty for my coffee. Many small coffee shops do provide better plant milk options like oat, so that is what I will go for if available. But it would be interesting to hear the science behind how these different plant milks might interact with coffee, and I think you could probably offer a lot of insight! And as always, thank you for the great and informative videos!
snippet.textOriginal:
​ James Hoffmann   This would be a great opportunity to do an exhaustive test of ALL of the plant milks and plant creamers!!! I meant, oat milk "minor figures' bran in particular is the most popular right now, but maybe a more elusive plant milk works better.   Things that come to mind: Macadamia milk, tiger nut milk, rice milk, pumpkin seed...There are also many different brands and type of creamers.  Some better for foaming than others. I think what I would be most interested in hearing from you and your advanced coffee palette is just how the various flavours of milks compliment coffee. 


In my own experience I find the plant milk options at Starbucks to be extremely disappointing. Soy, Almond, Coconut. 
I chose soy because it is the most neutral in flavour, and I personally don't have any problems digesting it, however I know many do.  On one occasion I ordered to coconut milk for my drink--now I'm not sure if the person just pulled a bad shot, or overheated the milk but the flavours just did not meld well. The coconut made it taste burnt (I have tried it on a few occasions and this flavour is consistent).  Almond on the other hand I just never cared for. The flavour is too nutty for my coffee. Many small coffee shops do provide better plant milk options like oat, so that is what I will go for if available. But it would be interesting to hear the science behind how these different plant milks might interact with coffee, and I think you could probably offer a lot of insight! And as always, thank you for the great and informative videos!

snippet.textDisplay:
Last time I went to Pakistan, I had a sort of coffee like this one, but they had an interesting way of making it.
First of all, they made the mousse via an espresso machine steamer, but they seemed to use the same ingredients. (Don't know about the ratios though) (And they appeared to use basic Nescafe instant coffee)
And then, instead of using cold milk as a base, they used hot milk and then mixed the whole thing.


Now back home, when this whole internet craze started, I made the two versions, the cold one tasted burnt and unpleasant but the hot one kind tasted much better, and I almost did not taste that "burnt" instant coffee after taste. Keep in mind, I followed the 1:1:1 ratio and used cheap super market label instant coffee (which tastes horrendous imo), and having no steamer, I hand whisked it. I hope that anyone reading this will give "hot" Dalgona Coffee a try (which we just call Desi Capuccino)
snippet.textOriginal:
Last time I went to Pakistan, I had a sort of coffee like this one, but they had an interesting way of making it.
First of all, they made the mousse via an espresso machine steamer, but they seemed to use the same ingredients. (Don't know about the ratios though) (And they appeared to use basic Nescafe instant coffee)
And then, instead of using cold milk as a base, they used hot milk and then mixed the whole thing.


Now back home, when this whole internet craze started, I made the two versions, the cold one tasted burnt and unpleasant but the hot one kind tasted much better, and I almost did not taste that "burnt" instant coffee after taste. Keep in mind, I followed the 1:1:1 ratio and used cheap super market label instant coffee (which tastes horrendous imo), and having no steamer, I hand whisked it. I hope that anyone reading this will give "hot" Dalgona Coffee a try (which we just call Desi Capuccino)

snippet.textDisplay:
So the Greeks make this uber-popular drink called the "Frappe'" with Nescafe. But it can be made black, without milk or sugar. Further differentiating it from the dalgona style is that cold water/ice is added on top afterwards.

The dilution starts out very small though, often with just a teaspoon or two of water. It can be mixed by hand, but most popularly a dedicated tool little stick agitator is used (which looks like some milk frothers or small milkshake mix heads). I suspect the melanoidins play a large role in keeping the foam stable, but most people attribute it to the dark magic of Nestle. Now to their credit, the Nescafe is sold as 100% coffee.

But I always suspected it had been conditioned in some manner. Having worked in a bakery, flour conditioners under a certain % were not required to be listed on labels or did not technically even count as "ingredients".
snippet.textOriginal:
So the Greeks make this uber-popular drink called the "Frappe'" with Nescafe. But it can be made black, without milk or sugar.  Further differentiating it from the dalgona style is that  cold water/ice is added on top afterwards.

The dilution starts out very small though, often with just a teaspoon or two of water. It can be mixed by hand, but most popularly a dedicated tool little stick agitator is used (which looks like some milk frothers or small milkshake mix heads). I suspect the melanoidins play a large role in keeping the foam stable, but most people attribute it to the dark magic of Nestle. Now to their credit, the Nescafe is sold as 100% coffee. 

But I always suspected it had been conditioned in some manner. Having worked in a bakery, flour conditioners under a certain % were not required to be listed on labels or did not technically even count as "ingredients".

snippet.textDisplay: Hello James , this actually is a greek Frappe coffee !! Right before being diluted with extra water in order to be drinkable using a straw ! Here in Greece we make this foam using 5-7 grams of instant coffee , the dosage of sugar (depending on the order ) and 30 ml of water ! Mixing them all together in the mixer , and then diluting with water ( adding ice) and that's a Frappe actually !
snippet.textOriginal: Hello James , this actually is a greek Frappe coffee !! Right before being diluted with extra water in order to be drinkable using a straw ! Here in Greece we make this foam using 5-7 grams of instant coffee , the dosage of sugar (depending on the order ) and 30 ml of water ! Mixing them all together in the mixer , and then diluting with water ( adding ice) and that's a Frappe actually !

snippet.textDisplay: I made it with espresso and it’s great! You have to whip a lot longer but with a hand mixer it didn’t take long for it to foam. The foam lasts long enough for you to drink your drink so the fact that it may be less stable didn’t effect me. I even left some left over foam in the fridge and it stayed foamy, it did start to separate a little so there was a little bit of coffee liquid at the bottom but once a stirred it, it was homogenous again.
snippet.textOriginal: I made it with espresso and it’s great! You have to whip a lot longer but with a hand mixer it didn’t take long for it to foam. snippet.textDisplay:
1: Medaglia D'oro instant espresso powder. 2: electric hand mixer. 3: stir the foam into the milk! when you see it not mixed it is just for pictures. you end up with a velvety, rich, soft mouth feel and delicious coffee.
You can also make your favorite coffee beans into instant coffee by grinding your beans, dehydrating them in the oven, and grinding them even finer
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: Hi James. Well, immediately thought of the "national drink of Greece", the frappe. I worked there in the 80's and did a bit of research into how it came about. Same type of foamy woamy coffee shake thing. So instead of a whisk, maybe a Vitamix or a shaker. A riff I did for my blog goes into greater details but, essentially, a Nescafe exec was trying to get into the Greek market with their instant coffee. At the same time in history Nestle was marketing a shaker for kids to use to make chocolate milk drinks. He discovered that he could foam and thicken instant coffee in one and the rest is history! Best regards from Houston. Jay. The link: http://www.houstonfoodexplorers.com/2018/05/coffee-summer-drinks-greek-frappe-iced.html
snippet.textOriginal: Hi James. Well, immediately thought of the "national drink of Greece", the frappe. I worked there in the 80's and did a bit of research into how it came about. Same type of foamy woamy coffee shake thing. So instead of a whisk, maybe a Vitamix or a shaker. A riff I did for my blog goes into greater details but, essentially, a Nescafe exec was trying to get into the Greek market with their instant coffee. At the same time in history Nestle was marketing a shaker for kids to use to make chocolate milk drinks. He discovered that he could foam and thicken instant coffee in one and the rest is history!  Best regards from Houston. Jay.  The link:   http://www.houstonfoodexplorers.com/2018/05/coffee-summer-drinks-greek-frappe-iced.html

snippet.textDisplay: Done this a few times and even my wife who isn’t a specialty coffee geek and loves sweet coffee with cream didn’t think it was worth the effort. Spot on about it tasting just like its components: sugar, milk, and instant coffee (which mixed together tastes like Korean iced coffee you can get at most Korean bakeries)

snippet.textDisplay: This process looks a lot like cafecito. I’ve seen methods where sugar is whipped with a little moka coffee to produce a foam. The difference being that rather than being added to milk, it’s added back to the moka coffee to produce a very sweet coffee with crema-looking foam.
snippet.textOriginal: This process looks a lot like cafecito. I’ve seen methods where sugar is whipped with a little moka coffee to produce a foam. The difference being that rather than being added to milk, it’s added back to the moka coffee to produce a very sweet coffee with crema-looking foam.

snippet.textDisplay: Me being the espresso enthusiast at heart was determined a way to make it work with less sugar. I used espresso, a lot less sugar, and one egg white for the topping and it was unbelievable fluffy and texture was better.  I know liability issues involved with telling others to consume raw eggs raises a lot of problems. I'd like to see other peoples thoughts/takes on this.

snippet.textDisplay:
You can actually make espresso foam. We did it back then in our café.
You put 1-2 shots of espresso on top of a few ice cubes (or you can do it without any ice) into a french press and then push it up and down furiously til it's thick enough. :D
And the foam can last pretty long.
snippet.textOriginal:
You can actually make espresso foam. We did it back then in our café.
You put 1-2 shots of espresso on top of a few ice cubes (or you can do it without any ice) into a french press and then push it up and down furiously til it's thick enough. :D
And the foam can last pretty long.

snippet.textDisplay: It's widely common in Greece, created by accident in 1957 by a Nestlé Greek employee, when he couldn't find hot water for his coffee. The non-milk version (which is the most popular) is called "frappé" (from the french word meaning "chilled") and the milk version is called "frapogalo" (a slang term-"gala" means milk in Greek). It's funny that it's been killing us for ages (it's really, really bad quality coffee) and now it's become popular! The most "healthy" iced coffee that we now make in Greece is freddo espresso or freddo cappuccino, similar to "caffè in ghiaccio" in Italy and "café helado" in Chile, for example. If I'm not mistaken, the first ever iced coffee was made in Algeria in 1840, called "mazagran".
snippet.textOriginal: It's widely common in Greece, created by accident in 1957 by a Nestlé Greek employee, when he couldn't find hot water for his coffee. The non-milk version (which is the most popular) is called "frappé" (from the french word meaning "chilled") and the milk version is called "frapogalo" (a slang term-"gala" means milk in Greek). It's funny that it's been killing us for ages (it's really, really bad quality coffee) and now it's become popular! The most "healthy" iced coffee that we now make in Greece is freddo espresso or freddo cappuccino, similar to "caffè in ghiaccio" in Italy and "café helado" in Chile, for example. If I'm not mistaken, the first ever iced coffee was made in Algeria in 1840, called "mazagran".

snippet.textDisplay:
I have just tried this, it's a naughty treat but you do need the good instant coffee, some local roasters here actually sell the same coffee that I buy whole bean, in instant packets. DO NOT use a straw a) you won't be able to clean it b)you need the taste of milk and this gooey mixture at the same time c) just don't use straws.
I used 1/4 cup of instant coffe, 1/4 granulated sugar, 1/4 cold water (filtered) and that was enough for 3 medium sized portions. I also grated some fresh nutmeg on top and it elevated the whole beverage. Hope this helps someone, and stay safe!
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay:
Tried using xanthan gum in place of sugar. Tl;dr: it works, but not how you would want

Used 1% by weight xanthan gum, omitted the sugar, and kept the 3:1 ratio of water to coffee.

Result was very foamy after only 90 seconds or so of whisking, but foam was too strong. It stuck to itself so well that you would either sip milk or foam, not both. Even mixing in the foam with a spoon didn't work; it just stuck to itself in smaller clumps. Not a great experience drinking lumpy coffee foam :/

On the upside, finally tried sightglass' instant packets.
snippet.textOriginal:
Tried using xanthan gum in place of sugar. Tl;dr: it works, but not how you would want

Used 1% by weight xanthan gum, omitted the sugar, and kept the 3:1 ratio of water to coffee. 

Result was very foamy after only 90 seconds or so of whisking, but foam was too strong. It stuck to itself so well that you would either sip milk or foam, not both. Even mixing in the foam with a spoon didn't work; it just stuck to itself in smaller clumps. Not a great experience drinking lumpy coffee foam :/

On the upside, finally tried sightglass' instant packets.

snippet.textDisplay: What "unpleasant compounds" are created when you heat coffee? Specifically, are these compounds created by a pot of coffee that sits on the the coffee maker heating element too long? Because the longer it sits on one of those, the worse the coffee tastes and I'd like to know the reasons it does that.
snippet.textOriginal: What "unpleasant compounds" are created when you heat coffee? Specifically, are these compounds created by a pot of coffee that sits on the the coffee maker heating element too long? Because the longer it sits on one of those, the worse the coffee tastes and I'd like to know the reasons it does that.

snippet.textDisplay:
When cleaning out coffee cups (with one of those pressurised hose sink-attachments you get in commercial kitchens) I found that left over batch brew bubbles up way more and for way longer than espresso dregs.

Do we think that the brewing method might have some knock on effects for a beverages propensity to foam ? The stability of the bubbles ? Perhaps in an interesting and, for the making of Dalgoda coffee, helpful way ?
snippet.textOriginal:
When cleaning out coffee cups (with one of those pressurised hose sink-attachments you get in commercial kitchens) I found that left over batch brew bubbles up way more and for way longer than espresso dregs.

snippet.textDisplay:
In Serbia we have something similar, called Ness Caffe, made from instant coffe. 
2 dcl cup, 1 tea spoon of instant coffe (it can go up to 2), sugar (per taste), small amount of hot water, use electric mixer (special for those type of coffe making) mix sit till you get same foam, and then add water (hot or cold) and or milk, depending what you like. Did not know, up until today, that it has fancy name :)
snippet.textOriginal:
In Serbia we have something similar, called Ness Caffe, made from instant coffe. 
2 dcl cup, 1 tea spoon of instant coffe (it can go up to 2), sugar (per taste), small amount of hot water, use electric  mixer (special for those type of coffe making) mix sit till you get same foam, and then add water (hot or cold) and or milk, depending what you like. Did not know, up until today, that it has fancy name :)

snippet.textDisplay:
Have you ever been to Greece? Are you familiar with greek cold coffee beverages?
They foam them up all the time. The most common one is the Nescafe Frape - whipped up instant coffee, often served with condensed milk (but can also be served milk free or with normal milk and WITH OR WITHOUT SUGAR). They also have what they call frento (fredo) espresso/cappucino - whipped up espresso over ice with or without milk (respectively).
The interesting bits here are:
1. Regarding machinery:
a. In cafes they use milkshake makers, as you'd suggested. this works, even though they do single servings.
B. more interestignly, they have frappe makers for home-use. These are similar to the battery operated hand held milk foamers that some people have, but with a head more like those of milk-shake makers (https://ae01.alicdn.com/kf/HTB15_M5KXXXXXcnXpXXq6xXFXXX2/15-Espresso-Machine-New-High-Quality-Electric-Handheld-Blender-Mixer-Maker-Frappe-Milk-Frother-Agitator-220.jpg)

2. Regarding why it foams:
a. while dilution plays a significant role, you can get very decent foam with one teaspoon of instant coffee, and about 40ml of water (which I think is far more diluted than espresso). However, you can't get anything close with espresso (it does foam up nicely, if you have a sufficiently powerful motor working there, but not as velvety and definitely not as stable).
b. Nescafe frappe gets a very nice texture with or without sugar, which means the stabalizing agents are probably in the instant coffee itself (sugar probably helps, but isn't necessary).

This leads me to think that maybe something about how instant coffee is made preserves more of the stabilizing powers of the coffee, or maybe that something about how espresso is made makes it go away.
Also, I feel like darker roasted coffee would probably have more melanoidins in them, and so would probably foam up better.

What do you think?
snippet.textOriginal:
Have you ever been to Greece? Are you familiar with greek cold coffee beverages?
They foam them up all the time. The most common one is the Nescafe Frape - whipped up instant coffee, often served with condensed milk (but can also be served milk free or with normal milk and WITH OR WITHOUT SUGAR). They also have what they call frento (fredo) espresso/cappucino - whipped up espresso over ice with or without milk (respectively).
The interesting bits here are:
1. Regarding machinery:
a. In cafes they use milkshake makers, as you'd suggested. this works, even though they do single servings. 
B. more interestignly, they have frappe makers for home-use. These are similar to the battery operated hand held milk foamers that some people have, but with a head more like those of milk-shake makers (https://ae01.alicdn.com/kf/HTB15_M5KXXXXXcnXpXXq6xXFXXX2/15-Espresso-Machine-New-High-Quality-Electric-Handheld-Blender-Mixer-Maker-Frappe-Milk-Frother-Agitator-220.jpg)

2. Regarding why it foams:
a. while dilution plays a significant role, you can get very decent foam with one teaspoon of instant coffee, and about 40ml of water (which I think is far more diluted than espresso). However, you can't get anything close with espresso (it does foam up nicely, if you have a sufficiently powerful motor working there, but not as velvety and definitely not as stable).
b. Nescafe frappe gets a very nice texture with or without sugar, which means the stabalizing agents are probably in the instant coffee itself (sugar probably helps, but isn't necessary).

This leads me to think that maybe something about how instant coffee is made preserves more of the stabilizing powers of the coffee, or maybe that something about how espresso is made makes it go away.
Also, I feel like darker roasted coffee would probably have more melanoidins in them, and so would probably foam up better.

What do you think?

snippet.textDisplay: Welcome to the "Balkan style" of making and drinking coffee. Here it is called Frappe or cold Nescafe (because it is made from Nescafe). You can use shaker to make a cream, just add Ice and shake it ;)
snippet.textOriginal: Welcome to the "Balkan style" of making and drinking coffee. Here it is called Frappe or cold Nescafe (because it is made from Nescafe). You can use shaker to make a cream, just add Ice and shake it ;)

snippet.textDisplay:
I waited for this. But:
Can you invent a new cold coffee drink with cream on top? Which is made out of "real" coffee?
I mean I could drink an iced coffee with vanilla icecream. But what if there is something better than that.
